Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 21.proposition: The Somerville District Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 21, and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord‑tenant relationship concerning real property located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction and the amount in controversy is within this Court’s jurisdictional limits.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Somerville District Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 21, and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord‑tenant relationship concerning real property located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction and the amount in controversy is within this Court’s jurisdictional limits.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 & 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the Property at issue is located within this county.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides that a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where noise from nearby lounge, operated by landlord’s tenant, substantially interfered with tenants’ ability to use apartments, even though landlord did not himself create the noise, because the landlord had the power and duty to control or abate the condition);
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords breached the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and that constructive eviction occurred due to excessive noise from a lounge operated by another tenant. The court emphasizes that, although the landlords did not themselves create the noise, they introduced the commercial use, had the right and ability to control or abate the objectionable conditions, and thus were liable and could not collect rent. This matches the proposition that a landlord can be liable for substantial interference from another tenant’s activities where the landlord has the power and duty to control the condition.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in ruling that the landlords had it within their control to correct the condition which caused the tenants to vacate their apartments…. We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (severe and repeated flooding and landlord’s failure to correct it constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment and supported damages for emotional distress);
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The case does involve severe and repeated flooding and recognizes that it caused the tenant severe emotional distress, but it does not ultimately sustain a damages award for emotional distress under the quiet enjoyment theory. The SJC vacated the $10,000 quiet-enjoyment award as duplicative, leaving recovery for emotional distress solely under a separate count for reckless infliction of emotional distress, not as damages flowing from breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not stand for the proposition that flooding and failure to correct it supported emotional distress damages under the quiet enjoyment claim itself, although it does hold that such flooding can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, taking into account the relationships among the three counts of Solomon’s claim, and the instructions that accompanied their submission to the jury, we find no acceptable basis for the verdict awarding $10,000 to Solomon for interference with quiet enjoyment. The jury could only have reached this verdict by duplicating items of damage subsumed in Solomon’s recoveries for breach of warranty and emotional injury, or by making unwarranted use of the triple rent clause of § 14. Accordingly, we vacate it.”

**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.proposition: **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (quiet enjoyment statute protects tenants from serious interferences “substantially impairing” the character and value of the leased premises, and the landlord’s knowledge and failure to act can constitute “indirect” interference);
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.support_reasoning: The court expressly describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leasehold, and applies that standard to the tenants’ inability to use common areas, stating this would “substantially” impair the character of the premises. It further explains that a landlord can breach the statute through omissions—what the landlord “failed to do” or “permitted to be done”—and holds that the landlord’s failure to take available measures against third-party drug activity can constitute an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment.
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.**, 41.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action … then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (reaffirming that a landlord’s inaction in the face of known conditions that seriously interfere with tenancy can amount to interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14).
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and reaffirms that a landlord’s liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment arises when the landlord has notice or reason to know of a serious condition and fails to act reasonably. The court characterizes prior § 14 cases, including Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, as involving landlords who “stood idle” in the face of tenant complaints, and then “make[s] clear” that at least negligent inaction regarding known problems that foreseeably interfere with tenancy is required for § 14 liability. That directly supports the proposition that inaction in the face of known, serious conditions can constitute interference under § 14.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt:
Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

… in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.proposition: **Winchester v. O’Brien**, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929) (landlord responsible when he permits acts which interfere with tenants’ enjoyment of leased premises);
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord is liable when he authorizes or voluntarily undertakes acts that substantially interfere with the tenant’s peaceful and beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises, even if the work is done reasonably and outside the demised space. The opinion frames the landlord’s responsibility in terms of refraining from such interfering acts and affirms damages based on that principle. This aligns with the proposition that the landlord is responsible when he permits acts that interfere with tenants’ enjoyment.
**Winchester v. O\u2019Brien**, 266 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
“The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ …
If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises and such a result is the natural and probable consequence of the acts so authorized, the landlord is liable therefor. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises….”

**Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott**, 312.proposition: **Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott**, 312 Mass. 375, 381–382 (1942) (covenant of quiet enjoyment extends to acts or omissions of the landlord that interfere with tenant’s beneficial use).
**Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott**, 312.support_reasoning: The court explicitly characterizes the eviction/quiet enjoyment doctrine as a contract-based obligation, stating that the landlord “impliedly warrants the quiet enjoyment of the demised premises” and that eviction may arise from a “breach, whether of commission or omission” that deprives the tenant of use and enjoyment. It then applies that principle to the landlord’s failure to remedy defective heating conditions, an omission that interfered with the tenant’s beneficial use and constituted constructive eviction, thereby excusing rent. This squarely supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment extends to acts or omissions of the landlord that interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use.
**Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott**, 312.relevant_excerpt: “The defence of eviction, actual or constructive, is based upon a failure of consideration, or a breach, whether of commission or omission, of a covenant of the lease so material as to excuse the tenant from performing. … It is a defence sounding in contract since the landlord impliedly warrants the quiet enjoyment of the demised premises… In all the circumstances we are of opinion that the landlord must be presumed to have intended the natural consequences of its own acts, subsequent to the installation of the oil burner, in failing to remedy the conditions which deprived the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises over a substantial period of time….”

**Manzaro v. McCann**, 401 Mass. 880, 88.proposition: The resulting chronic sleep deprivation, need for prescription sleep medication, expenditures for mitigation measures (earplugs, white noise machine), and the written workplace warning, constitute actual and consequential damages that are the foreseeable and direct result of Defendant’s interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
**Manzaro v. McCann**, 401 Mass. 880, 88.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that landlord-caused noise can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not address or discuss specific categories of consequential damages such as chronic sleep deprivation, prescription medication, mitigation expenditures, or employment-related discipline. The court focuses on whether a day-long alarm can, as a matter of law, amount to a breach warranting statutory damages (three months’ rent), not on the scope or types of actual or consequential damages recoverable. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the detailed damages proposition stated.
**Manzaro v. McCann**, 401 Mass. 880, 88.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord will be liable for interference with quiet enjoyment if he causes or authorizes acts which result in ‘substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises.’ … Landlord-caused noise may be sufficient to support a claim for interference with a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment. … We cannot say the judge’s conclusion to award damages under § 14 was wrong. … The ringing for a day of an alarm… cannot be said as a matter of law never to be sufficient interference to justify relief under § 14.”

**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as the express and implied covenant of quiet enjoyment contained in the Lease and recognized at common law.
**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a commercial tenant’s rights when a landlord breaches a covenant (here, to maintain the roof) and abolishes the independent covenants rule in favor of mutually dependent covenants. It analyzes constructive eviction and dependent covenants, not the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor any express or implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under the lease. The court instead finds there was no constructive eviction and bases relief on breach of a contractual maintenance promise, so it does not support the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constituted a breach of statutory or common-law quiet enjoyment covenants.
**Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.**, 4.relevant_excerpt: “We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. … While the landlord’s breach of his covenant to repair may have made the tenant’s operation less convenient and more expensive, based on the evidence adduced at trial, it did not rise to the level of a constructive eviction. … Having adopted a rule of mutually dependent covenants, we now consider whether the tenant was entitled to vacate the premises….”
